Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 08:44PM ernursen wrote: Correction:  Thanks to my awesome doc, she called to let me know I have about a dozen or so MICRO-calcifications but they are coarse in nature and are clustered.  Not exactly "good news" but a little more info.
Posts.Title: Large Coarse Clusterred Clacifications ernursen ernursen

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2008 03:20PM ernursen wrote: Beesie, your information has been priceless to me this weekend.  Thank you.  My breasts are small so my husband and I have talked extensively about our options if by chance my biopsy comes back "bad" and a lump to most might be just that, but that is all I have.  LOL.  I canll my gyn tomorrow to tell her who I would rather see for my biopsy.  Will keep you guys posted.
Posts.Title: Large Coarse Clusterred Clacifications ernursen ernursen

Posts.Content: ernursen wrote: Hi everyone.  My name is Nicole and I am 30 years old.  I felt a lump in my left brest a few weeks ago, so made an appt with my gyn and she referred me to get an ultrasound.  When I showed up at the Breast Cancer Clinic I was taken to the mammogram room.  I was explained that due to some of my risk factors they called my doctor and got the mammogram ordered.  Let me just say that it seriously was not as bad as I thought it would be.  That being said, after a mammogram and an ultrasound and being there for almost 3 hours (they took lots of pics in the mammogram) I was then seen by the radiologist.  I am a nurse so I knew that usually does not happen.  I just wanted to get my test and have my card mailed to me like everyone else.  I was told I had many large coarse and clusterred calcifications in my RIGHT breast.  I was very shocked.  Then I was told I would need a biopsy and he and my doctor think the surgical approach would be better for me and that I will here from a surgeon soon.  I am scared out of my mind.  I just had a close friend die of breast cancer earlier this year.  She was only 30 and was diagnosed when she was 27.  She fought so hard.  If anyone has dealt with this "diagnosis" please offer some education that you have personally learned.  The internet, even the medical sites have me really worried.  Thanks. “Life is full of beauty. Notice it. Notice the bumble bee, the small child, and the smiling faces. Smell the rain, and feel the wind. Live your life to the fullest potential, and fight for your dreams.” Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Large Coarse Clusterred Clacifications ernursen ernursen

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2008 07:54AM ernursen wrote: Beesie, how did you handle the early BC in your right breast?  Did you have a surgery for them to go "clean it out?"  I am praying min eis b9, but I have a bad feeling as did everyone it seemed in the breast clinic.
Posts.Title: Large Coarse Clusterred Clacifications ernursen ernursen

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2008 10:08PM ernursen wrote: I am menopausal due to complete hysterectomy 2 years ago.  I have always had small breasts and never did I think of myself as having dense breasts, but the report did say I was dense.  Maybe because of my age (30)?   I just do not like surprises and I would hate to think I am going for a biopsy and they find a mass the mammo missed.  This is all so confusing and I will be happy when it is over, no matter what the outcome.  I just want to KNOW so I can move forward.
Posts.Title: Should I request an MRI? ernursen dlb823

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2008 05:08PM ernursen wrote: Thank you for everyone's input.  To answer your question Ginger, everyone so far is leaning towards excisional due to the calcs' close proximity to the skin.  I found out today that my local hospital does not do breast MRIs so I am going to wait till I see my surgeon on the 24th and go from there.
Posts.Title: Should I request an MRI? ernursen dlb823

Posts.Content: ernursen wrote: Hi again.  :)  My mammo Fri revealed a cluster of microcalcs with no mass seen.  I have appt with surgeon on the 24th of this month.  My question is about asking for MRI.  A lot of the research I have done has said that masses can be missed on mammograms, but are found on MRI.  It seems to me that it is a fair thing to ask of my gyn, to order an MRI before I go see the surgeon, so there are no surprises during the excisional biopsy.  What do you all think?  You guys are angels and right now this site is helping me keep my sanity. Also, I know my score (?correct term) is BIRADS-4.  And reading the mammo report today states he feels I need to seek aggressive treatment.  If 4 is questionable, then why the urgency and why aggressive?  “Life is full of beauty. Notice it. Notice the bumble bee, the small child, and the smiling faces. Smell the rain, and feel the wind. Live your life to the fullest potential, and fight for your dreams.” Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Should I request an MRI? ernursen dlb823

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 08:04AM ernursen wrote: No biopsy yet.  That is coming.  Will keep you all posted.
Posts.Title: You guys are a source of calmness ernursen ernursen

Posts.Content: ernursen wrote: I just wanted to send a shout out and thank you all for your encouraging words of wisdom.  Since they first found my cluster of microcalcs, I have been visiting these boards everyday (sometimes it becomes all consuming) and I have even posted a few topics.  Last week, I was a ball of anxiety and now it seems like it is "old news."  I see the surgeon Monday and the anxiety may return on my long drive to see her, but like I said, now it just seems old.  I know in my gut and after seeing the rad report and films that I will not get good news, but I am already tired of people asking me if I am ok.  I feel fine and reading you guys' posts and stories, I am completly at ease and my husband and I have talked at great lengths about our furture options.  My spouse now says I am in denial.  I don't think so...but maybe?!  I don't know.  Anyone else feel like this? “Life is full of beauty. Notice it. Notice the bumble bee, the small child, and the smiling faces. Smell the rain, and feel the wind. Live your life to the fullest potential, and fight for your dreams.” Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: You guys are a source of calmness ernursen ernursen

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2008 07:37AM ernursen wrote: Also, I know that 80% of microcalcs (in general) are benign, but I haven't yet found the stat for 1 group of microcalcs in 1 breast.  Mostly I find that stats are about scatterred microcalcs or multiple groups and often involving bilat breasts.  Hmmmmm. Guess I truly won't know till my biopsy, which I hope comes soon after my consultation Monday.
Posts.Title: You guys are a source of calmness ernursen ernursen

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 08:46AM ernursen wrote: Thank you Sherry.  :)  I will send positive prayers your way paknew.  You sound a lot like me in our emotions on this stupid ride.  I guess I am calm now because I DO know what to talk about and questions to ask.  I feel much more informed than the first day.
Posts.Title: You guys are a source of calmness ernursen ernursen

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2008 04:50PM ernursen wrote: Yay!  Let's pray for B9.  I go for mine soon, met with specialist yesterday and their rad dept wants to review the films first so I am waiting to schedule.  The nurse said next week at the latest.  Good to hear it wasn't that bad.  My score is 4B  :(

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2008 03:55PM ernursen wrote: If the Ativan is too strong, you can ask to try something different.  I am unable to function on it, but I function like normal, but without the anxiety and panic, on Xanax.  Just some food for thought.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2008 02:14PM ernursen wrote: Bump.  I don't have a dx (just signs and symptoms), but this is for all the nurses who need to vent to other nurses.  Being a nurse has NOT really helped me in my journey thus far.  You guys have been absolutely wonderful and the information has been priceless.  I will meet with my surgeon (2nd opinion and she is a breast specialist) on the 16th.  Right now unsure of who I should call because I didn't have any palpable lymph nodes at the time of my radiologist's incidental finding, but now I have one.  Hmmmmm.... Nicole
